entry.title: Combined summary - "On behalf of" BIP 70 extension proposal
entry.summary: The context revolves around different discussions and email exchanges related to Bitcoin development. One such exchange involves Mark, who is informed that his proposal for a new Bitcoin feature is similar to a previous proposal. However, the details of the design are clear, and the two proposals do not differ substantially. In another exchange between Mark and Mike, they discuss the best way for a payment processor (PP) to issue non-SSL certificates for merchant identification. They debate various options, including a certificate chain to validate the entity generating the message and a signed mandate from the merchant granting the payment processor the right to collect payments on their behalf. The discussion focuses on balancing security concerns with backward compatibility.A conversation thread involves participants debating the best way for a payment processor (PP) to issue non-SSL certificates for merchant identification. They discuss the pros and cons of using X.509 certificates, merchant identifiers, Twitter handles, and extended certificates. The original poster clarifies that their proposal requires two signatures over the payment request data, one with the X.509 certificate key for backward compatibility and one with the ECDSA public key. Another participant suggests a simpler proposal that only requires one signature using the former key. The discussion centers on balancing security concerns with backward compatibility and considering the complexity of the proposed solutions.Mark and Mike discuss the implementation of a new BIP for formalizing the extensions process in another email exchange. They talk about how the extensions process should describe the proposal's process and express their frustration with payment processors not using useful memo fields. Mark offers to write the proposal for the new BIP, but they are unsure whether it should be a standalone BIP or part of BIP70. Their priority is to formalize the extensions process and work on improving the memo field.In summary, the discussions and email exchanges center on various aspects of Bitcoin development, including verifying merchant identity in online transactions, payment processor issues, and the formalization of the extensions process. The participants debate different solutions and consider the trade-offs between security concerns and backward compatibility.
